Award.AwardTitle: Nucleation and Growth of Anisotropic Magnetic Nanostructures
Award.AbstractNarration: The Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry program of the NSF Division of Chemistry and the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program of the Division of Materials Research supports the research project of Prof. Alexander Wei of Purdue University. Prof. Wei and his students will fabricate annular magnetic nanostructures on metal surfaces and focus primarily on the synthesis of cobalt nanometric rings. The group will investigate fundamental aspects of nucleation and growth in nanostructure synthesis and optimize the reaction conditions to realize templated anisotropic growth of the cobalt nanostructures. Cobalt nanostructures exhibit superb magnetic properties and controlling their dimensions at the nanometer scale will potentially led to the development of improved magnetic nanodevices. The project will also lead to the development of new concepts for non-voltaic memory and data processing, with potential for high density in 3D. The project will provide excellent training opportunities to undergraduate and graduate students in a highly interdisciplinary area at the forefront of science and nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The purpose of this project was to develop new methods of creating nanosized magnetic rings from cobalt (Co), with the intent of integrating them with other metallic nanostructures for the purpose of creating novel magnetoelectronic device elements. This project also supported the dissertation research of several graduate students (including a woman and a minority student), and produced two PhDs. 

One significant finding of this project is that Co nanoparticle rings of different sizes had variable responses to magnetic switching fields. In the absence of a magnetic field, small Co nanoparticle rings (<100 nm) support binary flux closure (FC) states with zero dipole that can be switched clockwise or counterclockwise. However, larger rings (>100 nm) support additional remanent states, such as "onion" states with a net dipole (see Figure 1). This has implications on the use of magnetic nanoparticle rings as futuristic data storage elements.

Another significant finding of this project is that cobalt nanocrystals could be grown from an amorphous phase (accretion) with good size control. The latter is important for producing magnetic nanoparticles with uniform behavior. From a more general perspective, the accretion model (see Figure 2) suggests an alternative method for producing nanocrystals of various material types, not just cobalt.


Last Modified: 09/03/2013
Modified by: Alexander Wei

Images (1 of )
  • Analysis of magnetic states in a Co nanoparticle ring using electron holography. A simplified model is provided to illustrate switching in magnetic states after exposure to different fields (A-D), between "onion" states (ON) and flux closure (FC).
    T. Kasama, Denmark Techn. Univ.
    Copyrighted
    Alexander Wei
    Figure 1. Multiple Magnetic States in Cobalt Nanoparticle Rings
  • In this model, two organometallic species (Co16-calixarene and PTC) are heated to form metastable nanoclusters within an amorphous matrix (accretion). The nuclei "pupate" within the accretion to form crystalline Co nanoparticles, before being released into solution.
    Alexander Wei
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The purpose of this project was to develop new methods of creating nanosized magnetic rings from cobalt (Co), with the intent of integrating them with other metallic nanostructures for the purpose of creating novel magnetoelectronic device elements. This project also supported the dissertation research of several graduate students (including a woman and a minority student), and produced two PhDs. One significant finding of this project is that Co nanoparticle rings of different sizes had variable responses to magnetic switching fields. In the absence of a magnetic field, small Co nanoparticle rings (<100 nm) support binary flux closure (FC) states with zero dipole that can be switched clockwise or counterclockwise. However, larger rings (>100 nm) support additional remanent states, such as "onion" states with a net dipole (see Figure 1). This has implications on the use of magnetic nanoparticle rings as futuristic data storage elements. Another significant finding of this project is that cobalt nanocrystals could be grown from an amorphous phase (accretion) with good size control. The latter is important for producing magnetic nanoparticles with uniform behavior. From a more general perspective, the accretion model (see Figure 2) suggests an alternative method for producing nanocrystals of various material types, not just cobalt.
